author: By Claire Moses
title: This Famous ‘Spy’ Whale Likes People. That Could Be a Problem.
description: A beluga whale named Hvaldimir was first spotted in 2019 wearing what looked like a camera harness. He has recently been moving toward busier waters, prompting fears for his safety.
content: Hvaldimir, a domesticated beluga whale that has been spotted in Scandinavian waters for years, was seen last week off the coast of Sweden, prompting concern among researchers who worry he could be in danger, especially if people don’t stay away from him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Is the Bear Market Over? It Depends.
description: The S&P 500 ended the day nearly 20 percent above its low last year, within a hair of a milestone for some market watchers. But assessing a bona fide bull market is not so simple.
content: The S&P 500, the index obsessed over by investors, executives and government officials, on Monday came close to finishing 20 percent above its lowest level of 2022, a gain that some on Wall Street see as the start of a bull market and a new phase of investing exuberance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Betsey Stevenson
title: Guess How Much This Debt Ceiling Nonsense Is Costing Us
description: The cost, financial and otherwise, of these debt-ceiling games is enormous.
content: Crisis averted; the debt ceiling has been raised. Before you turn your attention back to your summer travel plans and the challenges of inflation, let’s take stock of what these political shenanigans cost us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Burden of Proof’ and the Tony Awards
description: A brother investigates his sister’s 1987 disappearance in a new true crime series from HBO, and the 76th Annual Tony Awards air live on CBS.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 5-11. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Cornel West, Progressive Scholar, Announces Third-Party Bid for President
description: Dr. West said he would run as part of the People’s Party, which was founded by a former campaign staff member for Senator Bernie Sanders.
content: Cornel West, the progressive activist and professor, announced a presidential campaign on Monday with the People’s Party, a third party led by a former campaign staff member for Senator Bernie Sanders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Alyce McFadden and Linda Qiu
title: Robert Kennedy Jr., With Musk, Pushes Right-Wing Ideas and Misinformation
description: Mr. Kennedy, a long-shot Democratic presidential candidate with surprisingly high polling numbers, said he wanted to close the Mexican border and attributed the rise of mass shootings to pharmaceutical drugs.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a scion of one of the country’s most famous Democratic families, on Monday dived into the full embrace of a host of conservative figures who eagerly promoted his long-shot primary challenge to President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: He Devoted His Life to Compassion. His Killer Showed None.
description: After graduating from Stanford, David Breaux struggled to find his path — until he found his calling as “the Compassion Guy.”
content: It felt as if he had always been there, a steady sight on a busy corner in a college town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: ‘The Idol’ and Our Backlash Times
description: In HBO’s series, nostalgic sexism poses as transgression.
content: During the Trump presidency, one of the strongest currents in our culture was the struggle for social justice, from #MeToo to Black Lives Matter to the recognition of proliferating gender identities. Now, one of the strongest currents is the backlash to all of that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Is Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Here?
description: Also, train service resumes near India’s crash site.
content: Ukraine intensified attacks on Russian positions along many sections of the front line yesterday. U.S. officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the surge in attacks could indicate that Ukraine had begun an expected counteroffensive, which could be its best shot at regaining territory and coming to any peace negotiations with a strong hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman, Glenn Thrush and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Lawyers Visit Justice Dept. as Classified Documents Inquiry Nears End
description: Three lawyers representing the former president spent nearly two hours there after requesting a meeting to discuss their concerns about the department’s handling of the investigation.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump met on Monday at the Justice Department with officials, including the special counsel Jack Smith, two weeks after requesting a meeting to discuss their concerns about Mr. Smith’s investigations into Mr. Trump, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: ‘Pass Him’: How a British For-Profit College Made Millions
description: Oxford Business College and others like it make millions, largely by recruiting immigrants. They operate in an opaque corner of the British education system.
content: College recruiters walked immigrant neighborhoods, knocking on doors or stopping people in shopping malls, selling the merits of a business-school education and adding a surprising offer: Get paid to enroll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Poland Rejects E.U. Ruling, Restarting a European Feud
description: Poland’s justice minister called the E.U. court of justice “corrupt,” after it ruled a judicial overhaul was illegal. He vowed not to comply, though that could cost Poland billions.
content: Rattled by a protest march through Warsaw on Sunday by up to half a million people, many of them waving Polish and European Union flags, Poland’s nationalist government lashed out angrily on Monday at the latest legal setback in a long-running feud with the European bloc over the rule of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Robert Hanssen, F.B.I. Agent Exposed as Spy for Moscow, Dies at 79
description: Mr. Hanssen was sentenced to life in prison in 2002, bringing to a close one of the most lurid and damaging espionage cases in American history.
content: Robert P. Hanssen, a former F.B.I. agent who spied for Moscow off and on for more than two decades during and after the Cold War in one of the most damaging espionage cases in American history, was discovered dead in his prison cell in Colorado on Monday, federal authorities announced. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Real Solutions to Reduce Plastics Pollution
description: Two environmental organizations criticize the approach offered in an essay. Also: Trump’s MAGA army; Erdogan’s victory; canned music; A.I.; social media.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Millennials Just Keep Voting
description: They are voting at higher rates than younger adults once did, helping the Democratic Party.
content: In the 2018 elections — the midterms of Donald Trump’s presidency — turnout among younger voters surged. Almost twice as many people in their late 20s and early 30s voted that year as had done so in the midterms four years earlier. And they strongly backed Democratic candidates, helping the party retake control of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Andrés R. Martínez
title: Amsterdam Train Service Resumes After Disruption
description: The cause of the problem, which prompted widespread travel delays starting Sunday, had still not been determined.
content: Train service to and from Amsterdam was running normally on Monday afternoon after all trains were canceled a day earlier for technical reasons, even though the main problem had not been fully solved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Man Missing in Iowa Building Collapse Is Found Dead
description: Two other men remained missing a week after part of a building collapsed in Davenport, Iowa. Documents issued by city officials show the owner had been warned that part of the building was unstable.
content: The body of one of three men missing after the partial collapse of an apartment building in Davenport, Iowa, has been recovered a week after a section of the six-story structure collapsed, a spokeswoman for the city said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: When Society Collapses, These Traders Win Big
description: In “Chaos Kings,” Scott Patterson profiles the financiers who build their portfolios around daily losses, and — when disaster strikes — seismic gains.
content: Almost everyone knows someone who seems to take a perverse pleasure in imagining worst-case scenarios. In life, this is usually a coping mechanism devised to cushion the blows of disappointment. In markets, it is a way to make billions of dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Diablo IV Wants Gamers to Slay Monsters in Hell Forever
description: An addictive formula — kill enemies and collect the powerful gear they drop — is back, this time in a transformed video game industry where players now expect free content updates.
content: With hits like World of Warcraft and Diablo, Blizzard Entertainment is considered a progenitor of the “forever game,” addictive experiences that players cannot put down because they seemingly never run out of quests to complete or gear to collect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Eyes of the World Are Upon Ukraine
description: The moral equivalent of D-Day is happening right now.
content: Seventy-nine years ago Allied paratroopers began landing behind the beaches of Normandy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: A Good Walk, Filmed
description: Peter Callahan, a filmmaker in Hastings-on-Hudson, is the writer, director and star of a movie that takes its entire story from one man’s afternoon walk around his town.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. I’m on duty today as my colleague James Barron caps off a well-earned vacation. Today we’ll talk to a local filmmaker who uses Hastings-on-Hudson, the New York City suburb, as his muse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Oklahoma Approves First Religious Charter School in the U.S.
description: The school will offer online, Roman Catholic instruction funded by taxpayers. Its approval is certain to tee off a legal battle over the separation of church and state.
content: Oklahoma approved what would be the nation’s first religious charter school on Monday, handing a victory to Christian conservatives but opening the door to a constitutional battle over whether taxpayer dollars can directly fund religious schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thea Traff, Michael Paulson, Julia Jacobs and Amanda Webster
title: ‘It’s Intoxicating’: 39 Tony-Nominated Performers on Why They Act
description: Each year we photograph Tony nominees, and talk with them about their craft. This year we focused on actors.
content: What draws an actor to the stage? There’s the desire to be seen, sure, and a passion for storytelling. For some it feels like a calling; for others, a compulsion. A way to connect, or to feel. In preparation for this year’s Tony Awards, which take place on June 11, we asked Tony-nominated performers to reflect on why they do what they do. And, as we have done since 2018 (with a break for the pandemic), we took their pictures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken to Talk to Saudis About Normalizing Ties With Israel
description: U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will travel to Saudi Arabia to discuss the idea at a time when the politics in the three countries may make normalization difficult.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said Monday that he planned to talk to Saudi leaders and other Gulf state officials this week during a visit to Saudi Arabia about the possibility of the kingdom normalizing ties with Israel. The Biden administration supports such a move, but it should not come at the expense of “progress between Israelis and Palestinians” and a two-state solution, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Turning 100, the New Jersey Symphony Sticks to Home
description: The orchestra could have rented Carnegie Hall for the celebration, but “our supporters are here, our audiences are here,” its chief executive said.
content: When the New Jersey Symphony was planning this season’s centennial celebrations, which come to a close this weekend, a question kept coming up: Would the orchestra be going to Carnegie Hall?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Trooper Charged in Killing of Unarmed Man After a High-Speed Chase
description: Anthony Nigro IV was charged with first- and second-degree manslaughter in the 2022 death of James Huber.
content: A state trooper was charged by the New York attorney general’s office on Monday with killing an unarmed man in downtown Buffalo by shooting him after a high-speed highway chase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Ancient Human Relatives Buried Their Dead in Caves, New Theory Claims
description: Homo naledi, despite having tiny brains, may have lit fires and decorated walls around the graves of their dead, according to controversial new research.
content: In 2015, scientists reported an astonishing discovery from deep inside a South African cave: more than 1,500 fossils of an ancient hominin species that had never been seen before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Yankees Do ‘Winning Things’ as They Cross Their Fingers
description: A strong all-around series against the Dodgers showed the Yankees’ might, but now they will wait to see if Aaron Judge needs a trip to the injured list.
content: Gerrit Cole watched closely from the dugout on Friday night as the Los Angeles Dodgers pulverized his teammate, the right-hander Luis Severino. Cole was starting the middle game of the weekend series between the Yankees and the Dodgers, and what he saw of the lineup across the field, which has mashed more home runs than any other National League team, had him worried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 144 Picture Prompts to Inspire Student Writing
description: A school year’s worth of short, accessible image-driven posts that invite a variety of kinds of writing.
content: We’ve been publishing our Picture Prompts series four days a week since 2016. Below, we’ve rounded up all the prompts we published for the 2022-23 school year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: A ‘Lucky Child’ Writes His Way From Nigeria to the Global Stage
description: With a first novel that chronicles a love affair between two young men, 23-year-old Ani Kayode Somtochukwu asserts a commitment to “queer resistance.”
content: Ani Kayode Somtochukwu wrote his first novel without the benefit of the internet or even a computer. He scratched it out by hand on large white notepads, then transferred it, tap by tap, onto his cellphone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Where Do You Draw the Line on P.D.A.?
description: Wherever your boundaries are, they might not be as fixed as you think.
content: On a Wednesday afternoon in Manhattan, a man and a woman nestled closely beside each other on a bench in Washington Square Park. As the man leaned over and began gently massaging the woman’s upper thigh, she stabbed at the small bowl of mixed fruit in her lap with a fork and began to feed him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn and Bryan Anselm
title: The Mystery of the Vanishing Kestrels: What’s Happening to This Flashy Falcon?
description: The number of American kestrels has dropped sharply. That goes against the trend for birds of prey, broadly seen as a conservation bright spot.
content: At first, people thought it might be a housing shortage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Apes Together Strong’ Review: Rooting for the Small Investors
description: The 2021 “short squeeze” of GameStop was a rare victory for the little guy. This documentary explains why the house — Wall Street wealth, that is — almost always wins.
content: If we accept the proposition that having money is sexy, we should also be able to admit that the most aggressive ways of making lots of money — the banking schemes and strategies that compound the wealth of the already rich — are not. Are they unfair to the working class? Certainly. Possibly criminal? Sure. But sexy, no. Among the more nefarious activities known to capitalism, big investing is particularly dry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Benjamin Mullin
title: Chris Licht of CNN Faces a Crisis. Here’s Why.
description: Mr. Licht, the network’s chief executive, said on an internal call on Monday that he would “fight like hell” to win back the trust of the network.
content: Ratings have plummeted. Profits have shrunk. A top star has been pushed out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Julian E. Barnes, Adam Entous, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
title: Fighting is raging at several points on the front line, Russian and U.S. officials say.
description: Ukrainian forces stepped up their artillery strikes and ground assaults in a flurry of offensive military activity that by Monday was raging along multiple sectors of the front line, American and Russian officials said.
content: Ukrainian forces stepped up their artillery strikes and ground assaults in a flurry of offensive military activity that by Monday was raging along multiple sectors of the front line, American and Russian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: At Least 42 Are Dead and Thousands Are Displaced After Flooding in Haiti
description: Officials said that western portions of the country appeared to be the most affected by the flooding caused by heavy rain over the weekend.
content: At least 42 people were dead and thousands were displaced after a weekend of heavy rainfall and widespread flooding in Haiti, the country’s disaster response agency said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: M.T.A. Looks Beyond Enforcement After $690 Million in Fare Evasion
description: A study proposed new approaches to get riders to pay to ride New York City’s transit system, including replacing subway turnstiles with fare gates that are harder to jump over.
content: For years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has mostly relied on the same approach to deter people from sneaking into New York City’s subways without paying. As passengers trickle in, police officers stand next to turnstiles and write tickets to those who jump them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen and Justin Porter
title: Has Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Begun?
description: Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: In a sudden flurry of military activity, Ukrainian forces have ramped up their artillery strikes and ground assaults at several points along the front line. Russian officials reported major Ukrainian attacks at five different locations in the eastern region of Donetsk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Queen Victoria’s Son Was the Last British Royal to Testify in Court
description: Prince Harry’s expected courtroom testimony this week will be the first time that a prominent member of Britain’s royal family has been cross-examined in over 130 years.
content: Prince Harry’s expected testimony on Tuesday in a phone-hacking case will be the first time in over 130 years that a prominent member of Britain’s royal family is cross-examined in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: When Wine Becomes Crucial to Cultural Identity
description: Throughout history, and even now in politically unstable regions, autocrats seek to control wine. For many people, it is worth defending.
content: For most people, wine is a commodity on a shelf, a treat for when the mood strikes. For the mass-market companies, wine might as well be pencils or paper towels — merchandise to move. But for serious-minded producers and fans, wine has a far deeper meaning that cuts almost to the core of human existence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: N.Y.P.D. Anti-Crime Units Still Stopping People Illegally, Report Shows
description: Mayor Eric Adams revived the teams, promising they would be well trained and supervised. But a new report found widespread use of stop-and-frisk tactics against people of color.
content: The New York Police Department’s anti-crime units are still stopping, frisking and searching too many people unlawfully — almost all of them people of color — despite assurances from Mayor Eric Adams that new policies and training would end the practice, according to a new report by a court-appointed monitor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Nazi Symbols on Ukraine’s Front Lines Highlight Thorny Issues of History
description: Troops’ use of patches bearing Nazi emblems risks fueling Russian propaganda and spreading imagery that the West has spent a half-century trying to eliminate.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Since Russia began its invasion of Ukraine last year, the Ukrainian government and NATO allies have posted, then quietly deleted, three seemingly innocuous photographs from their social media feeds: a soldier standing in a group, another resting in a trench and an emergency worker posing in front of a truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Andrew Bellucci, Pizza Visionary With a Troubled Past, Dies at 59
description: His obsession with recreating the original New York pizza helped revive a classic and inspire a generation of chefs. But his ambitions led to conflicts and, once, prison.
content: Andrew Bellucci, who in the 1990s became one of the first chefs in New York City to achieve fame for pizza, then lost his job and reputation when an old crime caught up with him, only to return more than two decades later to a city full of pizzaioli inspired by his artisanal, traditionalist approach, died on Wednesday in Queens. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Megan Specia
title: With Prince Harry to Testify in Hacking Case, Royals Prepare to Cringe
description: A media spectacle will unfold this week as the prince prepares to take the stand against newspapers he says invaded his privacy by hacking his cellphone.
content: Prince Harry’s bitter, yearslong feud with Britain’s tabloid press will come to a head this week. He is scheduled to take the stand on Tuesday in a London courtroom for a lawsuit against the Mirror newspaper group on charges that it hacked his cellphone more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simone Stolzoff
title: Please Don’t Call My Job a Calling
description: The idea that a job is a passion obfuscates the reality that a job is an economic contract — setting up the conditions for exploitation.
content: Last month, in an interview about Warner Bros. Discovery’s $50 million streaming profit in the first quarter of 2023, the company’s chief executive, David Zaslav, told CNBC that he believed the Writers Guild of America strike would ultimately end because of “a love for the business and a love for working.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Fake Putin Speech Calling for Martial Law Aired in Russia
description: The Kremlin said it was investigating what it called a “hack” after a bogus speech aired on some radio and television networks.
content: A faked declaration of martial law and military mobilization by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia aired Monday on a number of Russian radio and television networks, an incident that the Kremlin described as a “hack.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Jacinda Ardern, New Zealand’s Ex-Leader, Is Now Dame Jacinda Ardern
description: Ms. Ardern, who stepped down as prime minister in January, said she had considered declining the title, but accepted it as a way to show gratitude.
content: Jacinda Ardern was awarded the title of dame on Monday for service to New Zealand, barely four months after ending her term as prime minister, during which she became the global face of a compassionate brand of liberal politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Decide ‘Trump Too Small’ Trademark Dispute
description: In earlier cases, the justices struck down provisions of the trademark law that discriminated based on the speaker’s viewpoint.
content: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether a California lawyer may trademark the phrase “Trump too small,” a reference to a taunt from Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, during the 2016 presidential campaign. Mr. Rubio said Donald J. Trump had “small hands,” adding: “And you know what they say about guys with small hands.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Economics and Hamlet Have in Common
description: Like many philosophers before them, modern economists tend to believe that virtue can be learned.
content: In high school I memorized a scene from “Hamlet” in which the gloomy prince tries to persuade his mother to leave the usurper king, the brother of Hamlet’s murdered father. “Assume a virtue, if you have it not,” Hamlet implores Gertrude. And a few lines later: “Refrain tonight, / And that shall lend a kind of easiness / To the next abstinence: the next more easy; / For use almost can change the stamp of nature.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Meyer
title: The Supreme Court Is Wrong About Andy Warhol
description: The artist was never concerned about copyright. He cared more about the right to copy, as an artistic method and a design for living.
content: The Supreme Court got it wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Roger Craig, Teacher of an Era-Defining Pitch, Is Dead at 93
description: After winning three World Series as a player, Craig became a coach and spread the gospel of the split-fingered fastball, what one player of the time called “the pitch of the ’80s.”
content: Roger Craig, who pitched or managed in five World Series and changed the face of pitching in the 1980s as the guru of the split-fingered fastball, died on Sunday. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Judge Delays 9/11 Hearings While Awaiting Defendant’s Competency Exam
description: The military judge postponed resumption of testimony in the long-running case until after the 22nd anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.
content: The military judge in the Sept. 11 case postponed this summer’s hearings on Monday, citing a pending evaluation of whether one of the five men accused of conspiring in the attacks is competent to face trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Stefanos Tsitsipas Picks Up Doubles Tennis and His Kid Brother
description: Tsitsipas is aiming to beat Carlos Alcaraz in Paris on Tuesday in a French Open quarterfinal, but what he really wants is to help turn his younger brother Petros into a doubles champion.
content: Stefanos Tsitsipas already had a lot going on as he arrived at the French Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and James Hill
title: The Evolving, Enduring Superstardom of Yannick Noah
description: To the world, Noah is the last Frenchman to win his country’s Grand Slam tournament. In France, his legacy and life loom over every man who has played tennis.
content: Yannick Noah was nervous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Mike Pence Formally Enters 2024 Race, Challenging Trump
description: Mr. Pence, who filed paperwork declaring his candidacy, was once a stalwart supporter and defender of Donald J. Trump, but split with his former boss after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence filed paperwork on Monday declaring his presidential candidacy, embarking on a long-shot campaign against the former president he served under, Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Heat, a Long Shot in the Playoffs, Pull Even With Long Shots
description: Miami, usually outgunned by the Denver offense, made 17 3-pointers to even the N.B.A. finals at one game apiece.
content: Michael Malone is generally the kind of coach who would leave a negative Yelp review after vacationing in Shangri-La. But his worry was warranted this time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: A Gay Riot at a Doughnut Shop? The Legend Has Some Holes.
description: As Los Angeles prepares to commemorate the long-gone Cooper Do-nuts, accounts of a renowned 1959 uprising at one of its stores are being called into question.
content: The story still resonates: More than 60 years ago, Los Angeles police officers were routinely harassing the gay and transgender people who gathered at Cooper Do-nuts, a 24-hour spot in the city’s seedy gay circuit known as the Run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Home Insurance Is Getting Trickier. Here’s How to Optimize Your Coverage.
description: The insurance industry is reacting to natural disasters by raising rates, reducing coverage and exiting some markets entirely.
content: In 2016, when Shawn Loht bought his house near New Orleans, he easily found homeowner insurance with a $2,000-a-year premium. “It was just lickety-split,” he said. But after Hurricane Ida, a Category 4 storm, barreled through Louisiana in 2021, his premium jumped to $6,109. Then his provider failed, leaving him facing a premium of nearly $13,000 a year from the state’s insurer of last resort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Halts Morgan Wallen’s Run at No. 1
description: After 12 straight weeks at the top, the country star’s “One Thing at a Time” yields to Swift’s “Midnights,” which was reissued in expanded editions.
content: For 12 weeks, nothing could stop Morgan Wallen’s domination of the Billboard chart with his latest album, “One Thing at a Time.” Not Metallica. Not Ed Sheeran. Not the Jonas Brothers or solo projects from two members of BTS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Richard Ford’s New Novel, One More Trip for Old Times’ Sake
description: “Be Mine” is the fifth book featuring Ford’s keen observer of American life, Frank Bascombe.
content: Richard Ford has long been our chief literary appraiser of bad men’s wear. Philip Roth also had an eye for this sort of thing. In “American Pastoral,” a loud shirt worn by a country-club type is “WASP motley.” But Ford is in a league of his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Why America Desperately Needed Ted Lasso
description: He is a broken human being who has not yet lost faith in the promise of wholeness.
content: NASHVILLE — I didn’t watch the first season of “Ted Lasso” until the second season was already underway on Apple TV+. I wish I’d been watching from the very beginning, when it first began streaming in 2020. It would have made me feel better during a national election season — not because the show is even winkingly political but because its characters are so utterly, inescapably human. Humanity felt sorely lacking from public life in those days.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Vigilantes Make Streets in Haiti Calm Yet Uneasy
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 5, 2023.
content: “Fear has changed sides.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Tim Scott Defends Remarks on Race on ‘The View’
description: The presidential candidate went on the daytime talk show to debate his views about systemic racism. But it was his comments about L.G.B.T.Q. rights that got boos from the audience.
content: The chatty daytime talk show “The View” might seem like an unlikely platform for Tim Scott, a senator from South Carolina and a presidential candidate, to get his footing with Republican primary voters, but he saw an opening on Monday and tried to make the most of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Donald Trump Wants to Throw America a ‘Most Spectacular’ Party
description: His proposed celebration to mark the 250th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence is exquisitely on brand.
content: Break out those party pants: Donald Trump wants to throw America a birthday bash for the ages!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Edgar Sandoval and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Second Plane Carrying Migrants Arrives in Sacramento
description: As California officials accused Florida of shipping migrants to its capital city last week, about 20 more people, mostly from Venezuela, arrived on Monday on the same chartered plane.
content: A group of Latin American migrants aboard a chartered private plane landed at a small airport in Sacramento on Monday, the second such planeload in three days to arrive in California’s capital city from an airfield in New Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Can Christie Succeed as ‘Trump Slayer’? New Jersey Has Thoughts.
description: The former governor, with his ready wit and considerable baggage, intends to jump into the Republican presidential primary on Tuesday.
content: Chris Christie left office in New Jersey with abysmal popularity ratings. His 2016 presidential run was a short-lived flop. He has a reputation as a bully and is perhaps best known for a notorious political retribution scheme called Bridgegate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 5, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 5, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Armed Guard Is Charged With Raping a Migrant at a Federal Building
description: The guard, Jimmy Solano-Arias, forced a migrant, who was waiting to file an asylum application, to perform oral sex on him, federal prosecutors said.
content: A security guard who worked at a federal building in Manhattan has been accused of forcing an asylum seeker to perform oral sex on him, violating the migrant’s constitutional rights, federal prosecutors said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Citing Doubt, Officials Free Woman Convicted in 4 Children’s Deaths in 2003
description: An Australian jury found that Kathleen Folbigg had smothered her children. But scientists now say that they probably died from natural causes.
content: Two decades ago, Kathleen Folbigg was convicted of smothering all four of her young children. Australian tabloids called her the country’s worst female serial killer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Missouri Governor Says Execution Will Proceed After Jurors Waver on Death Sentence
description: Michael Tisius, convicted in the murders of two jail guards, is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday.
content: Gov. Mike Parson of Missouri said on Monday that he would not intervene to stop the execution of Michael Tisius, a 42-year-old who murdered two jail guards in 2000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: The Lifelong Gift of Sibling Friendship
description: Whether you’ve always been close, or wish you got along better, here’s how to bolster your connection.
content: Sisters Audrey Findlay, 75, and Barbara Rowe, 63,  start every weekday with an 8 a.m. phone call. An hour or so later, they head to work together at Findlay Rowe, the gift shop they opened 12 years ago. (Previously, they worked at the same health care company for 13 years, where Ms. Findlay was the general manager and Ms. Rowe was the payroll manager.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Howe Verhovek
title: Where Whales, Puffins and Icebergs Jostle for Your Attention
description: Each spring, opalescent icebergs from the Greenland ice sheet pass through Iceberg Alley, off the eastern edge of Canada, on a slow-motion journey southward.
content: “I never trust the mind of an iceberg,” Cecil Stockley told me. He estimates its length, multiplies by five and keeps his boat at least that distance away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘The Idol’ Series Premiere Recap: Does it Live Up (or Down) to the Hype?
description: Is this show about a pop star’s liberation or her subjugation? After Sunday night’s premiere, it’s still hard to tell.
content: In the background of an early scene in the new HBO series “The Idol” you can hear Fiona Apple’s 1990s hit “Criminal.” The pop star heroine of the series, Jocelyn (Lily-Rose Depp), is posing for her album cover. Her breasts are bare, and she stares seductively into the camera. An intimacy coordinator bursts in and tells the photographer to stop shooting. Areolas are not allowed per the nudity rider — a detail that neither Jocelyn nor her team seem to care about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Ama Ata Aidoo, Groundbreaking Ghanaian Writer, Dies at 81
description: A playwright, novelist and poet, she was a leading African writer who explored the complexities faced by modern women living in the shadow of colonialism.
content: Ama Ata Aidoo, a Ghanaian playwright, author and activist who was hailed as one of Africa’s leading literary lights as well as one of its most influential feminists, died on Wednesday. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Takeaways From Nikki Haley’s Mild CNN Town Hall
description: The former South Carolina governor, who also served as United Nations ambassador under Donald Trump, emphasized her experience and vision. Will it be enough for her to stand out?
content: Nikki Haley, who was the first prominent Republican to announce a challenge to former President Donald J. Trump in the 2024 race, has yet to see her presidential campaign catch fire. On Sunday night, she had a fresh opportunity to make the case for her candidacy during a 90-minute CNN town hall in prime time, in an effort to emerge from the low single digits in polls where she has been mired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
title: As Ukrainian Attacks Surge, U.S. Officials See Signs of Counteroffensive
description: Kyiv has not formally announced the start of operations. But Russia said that major Ukrainian attacks had begun in the Donetsk region and that it had repelled the assaults and inflicted casualties.
content: Ukrainian forces have stepped up artillery strikes and ground assaults in a flurry of military activity that American officials suggested on Monday could signal that Kyiv’s long-planned counteroffensive against Russia had begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: The 2024 G.O.P. Field Balloons This Week, Adding 3 New Candidates
description: Chris Christie and Doug Burgum are set to announce their presidential campaigns this week, and Mike Pence has already filed paperwork.
content: The growing field of Republicans running for president is set to expand by three this week, with former Vice President Mike Pence filing paperwork on Monday and former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota expected to do so soon. The field continues to expand in part because hopefuls see opportunity in the struggle of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida to become the undisputed challenger to former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Invites Allies to Washington as Fighting Intensifies in Ukraine
description: President Biden hosted Mette Frederiksen, the prime minister of Denmark, at the White House on Monday, and much of the discussion revolved around providing support to Kyiv.
content: President Biden hosted Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark at the White House on Monday to discuss security initiatives, including providing military support to Ukraine, amid reports that Kyiv may be stepping up its long-planned counteroffensive against Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Hundreds Dead in India Train Crash, and Other Top Stories
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Hundreds of Gannett Journalists Walk Out
description: The union representing the company’s newsroom employees criticized the C.E.O. for cutting jobs and hurting local journalism.
content: Hundreds of journalists for Gannett, the country’s largest newspaper chain, walked off the job on Monday, accusing the company’s chief executive of decimating its local newsrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia says it repelled a large-scale Ukrainian assault.
description: Ukrainian ground forces tried to break through Russian defenses in eastern Ukraine, in an area of the front that had not shifted significantly for months, and staged large-scale assaults across much of the frontline, Russian authorities and military bloggers aligned with the Kremlin said Monday.
content: Ukrainian ground forces tried to break through Russian defenses in eastern Ukraine, in an area of the front that had not shifted significantly for months, and staged large-scale assaults across much of the frontline, Russian authorities and military bloggers aligned with the Kremlin said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: All 3 Missing in Iowa Building Collapse Found Dead, Officials Say
description: Moves to swiftly demolish the stricken building last week were halted by protests because three occupants were unaccounted for. Their bodies were uncovered in the rubble.
content: The police in Davenport, Iowa, said on Monday that they had found the bodies of all three men who had been missing since a section of a downtown apartment building collapsed last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Up Late With Vermeer, as a Blockbuster Comes to an End
description: At two extended viewings this past weekend, some of the last visitors saw the show at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam that many wanted to experience, but only a lucky 650,000 people could.
content: To become one of the last lucky last visitors to the landmark “Vermeer” exhibition, Kristian Markus of Hamburg, Germany, drove five hours on Saturday to make it to the Rijksmuseum by midnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Jenny Lewis Keeps Finding the Magic
description: In her new album, “Joy’All,” Lewis grapples with aging and life cycles. “Having survived this moment, I felt like it was important to project something joyful,” she said.
content: Jenny Lewis didn’t mean to wind up with the marimba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: How to Amplify Your Wordle Game
description: Introducing Wordle Golf, a new competitive way to play the daily guessing game.
content: According to the PGA, the odds of an average golfer making a hole in one are 12,500 to 1. The odds of solving Wordle on the first guess are around a couple thousand to one. (We can’t give away our secret sauce!) Basically, it’s easier to solve Wordle than to play golf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Investigations into a train crash in India.
content: The authorities in India have intensified the investigation into the causes of a devastating three-way train crash in which 275 people died. While officials were looking into the malfunction of an electronic signaling system, they had not ruled out human error — or even sabotage — and vowed punishment for those responsible, India’s railway minister, Ashwini Vaishnaw, said yesterday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: The Relief: Finding an Apartment. The Remorse: Living In It.
description: A couple felt obligated to take the first apartment they saw in a crazy rental market. Then they wanted to move again, but cooler heads prevailed.
content: Rebecca Strassberg was fortunate. She had a deep and important relationship that lasted four years — with her studio apartment in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.3 Million Homes in California
description: A one-bedroom bungalow with a guesthouse in Los Osos, an 1870 Victorian in San Francisco and a three-bedroom cabin in Lake Arrowhead.
content: This house is a 10-minute drive from the El Moro Elfin Forest, a 90-acre nature preserve popular with hikers and bird-watchers. It is also close to the shoreline of Morro Bay and to Baywood Park Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Hwaida Saad
title: As Assad’s Isolation Lifts, Syrian Refugees Fear Pressure to Return Home
description: Arab countries re-establishing diplomatic ties with Syria are making repatriation of Syrian refugees a top priority. “Even if they shoot me, I won’t go back,” a refugee in Lebanon said.
content: Early one recent morning, Lebanese soldiers swept through the Bourj Hammoud neighborhood in Beirut, emptying two buildings of the Syrian refugees living in them. They forced them into trucks and drove them to a no-man’s land between the Lebanese and Syrian borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Learn About Edible Plants of the Caribbean at the New York Botanical Garden
description: Attend the talk with Jessica B. Harris and Jamaica Kincaid, pick up a whiskey sampler for Father’s Day, and more food news.
content: The African American Garden at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx has inspired a program on June 17, during the weekend before Juneteenth, to highlight the plants and foods of the Caribbean. From 10 a.m. until noon, there will be a conversation between the scholar Jessica B. Harris and the writer Jamaica Kincaid about the edible plants of the Caribbean, followed by a panel discussion about sugar moderated by the food historian Scott Alves Barton. The event will be held in the Arthur and Janet Ross Lecture Hall. Free registration is required, which includes grounds-only admission to the garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
title: Biden Administration Shrugs Off Ukraine’s Attacks in Russia
description: For months, U.S. officials said cross-border operations risked a dangerous escalation. But those fears have ebbed.
content: During the first year of Russia’s war in Ukraine, the Biden administration fretted constantly that if Kyiv hit back inside Russian borders, President Vladimir V. Putin would retaliate against not only Ukraine, but also possibly NATO and the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: An Amateur Sleuth Heads to the Sierra in Search of the Zodiac Killer’s Tracks
description: Fayçal Ziraoui flew to California from France, believing that the serial killer may have left a rock formation near a desolate lake.
content: Late last year, Fayçal Ziraoui, a French-Moroccan business consultant, was at his home in the Paris suburbs scrolling through satellite pictures of the Sierra Nevada when he came across an image that startled him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Adam Goldman
title: Republicans, Escalating Attacks on F.B.I., Vow to Hold Director in Contempt
description: F.B.I. officials briefed lawmakers on an unsubstantiated bribery allegation against Joe Biden when he was vice president, but did not let them leave a secure area with a document detailing it.
content: House Republicans said on Monday that they would move this week to hold the F.B.I. director, Christopher A. Wray, in contempt of Congress, escalating their attacks on the federal law enforcement agency as they grasp for evidence of wrongdoing by President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Paris
title: See the States That Have Passed Laws Directed at Young Trans People
description: More than 20 Republican-led states have passed bills regulating the lives of transgender children and adolescents since the start of 2021.
content: State laws restricting transition care for minors have surged over the past few months, as part of a Republican movement to regulate the lives of transgender youth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Chris Sununu Says He Won’t Run for President
description: Mr. Sununu, the governor of New Hampshire, is more moderate than many members of his party and would have tested Republican voters’ appetite for a self-described “normal” candidate.
content: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire will not enter the Republican presidential race, he said on Monday, forgoing a campaign that would have tested the appetite of his party’s voters for a self-described “normal” candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: endeavor
description: This word has appeared in 299 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word endeavor has appeared in 299 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 25 in “An Art Patron’s Mission to Share Her Collection With the World” by Laura Rysman:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Saudi Arabia’s ‘Whatever It Takes’ Strategy Boosts Oil Prices
description: Brent crude rose on Monday after the world’s biggest oil producer announced it would be the lone OPEC Plus member to cut production next month.
content: Crude oil and natural gas rebounded this morning after Saudi Arabia, the world’s biggest exporter, announced a million-barrel-per-day production cut at this weekend’s OPEC Plus summit in an effort to boost sagging energy prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of May 29, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Tiffany Hsu
title: Twitter’s U.S. Ad Sales Plunge 59% as Woes Continue
description: In internal forecasts, the company projected that ad sales would keep declining, handing a tough challenge to its new chief executive.
content: Elon Musk recently said Twitter’s advertising business was on the upswing. “Almost all advertisers have come back,” he asserted, adding that the social media company could soon become profitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar, Isabella Kwai and Sameer Yasir
title: In India, Trains Start Running Again by Devastating Crash Site
description: The restoration of service could help more families reach the area to identify the dead. Officials said about 100 victims were still unclaimed.
content: A coal train, blaring its horn in the dark, was the first of dozens of trains to rumble past the Bahanaga Bazar rail station, the site of one of the deadliest train disasters in India’s history, as rail lines reopened there after midnight on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: The Crispiest Chicken Cutlets You Can’t Mess Up
description: Alexa Weibel’s new chicken Milanese makes golden, crispy cutlets truly foolproof for the fry-phobic.
content: Happy Monday, everyone. Margaux Laskey here, filling in for Melissa Clark today. Big shoes to fill! But I’m happy to be here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
title: Nearly 90 Afghan Schoolgirls Were Poisoned, Officials Suspect
description: Students and staff members at two schools in northern Afghanistan fell ill with respiratory and neurological symptoms.
content: Eighty-nine schoolgirls and their teachers in northern Afghanistan were hospitalized with respiratory and neurological symptoms over the weekend in what officials believe were deliberate poisonings at two girls’ schools, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Blessings to You, Chris Christie
description: Biden-Trump, the sequel, has quite a few plot twists.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. A recent CNN poll shows that 20 percent of Democrats favor Robert F. Kennedy Jr. for the party’s nomination, 8 percent want Marianne Williamson and another 8 percent want someone else. That’s 36 percent saying they aren’t thrilled with the presumptive nominee. Do you think this is some kind of polling fluke or an ominous political sign for Joe Biden?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Clare Toeniskoetter, Eric Krupke, Nina Feldman, Anita Badejo, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: The New Afghanistan, Through the Eyes of Three Women
description: How lives have changed under the Taliban’s increasingly restrictive rule.
content: This episode contains descriptions of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: I’m Traveling in Both the City and the Country. What Shoes Should I Pack?
description: A suitcase can fit only so many shoes. A reader wonders which will guarantee style and comfort on an all-terrain vacation.
content: Packing shoes for summer travel is like trying to solve a Sudoku puzzle: You need to figure out how all the exigencies add up in multiple directions before you make a choice. After all, shoes are bulky, so you don’t want to take too many, which means each pair has to play multiple parts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Margalit
title: A Hijacked Plane, a Childhood Trauma Long Repressed
description: In a new memoir, the historian Martha Hodes explores her recollections of being held hostage on an airplane in 1970.
content: In the late 1960s and early ’70s, a new form of terrorism rattled the international order. Militants from a nascent Marxist-nationalist revolutionary movement called the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine began to hijack passenger planes — repeatedly, all over the globe — in an attempt to bring about the release of Palestinian prisoners in Israel and Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia Lam
title: I’m in High School. I Hope Affirmative Action Is Rejected and Replaced With Something Stronger.
description: Asian students lose out with this college admissions system, but so do low-income ones.
content: The Supreme Court will soon decide the fate of race-based affirmative action in college admissions. Its ruling will be of particular interest to my class — high school juniors who would be the first affected by a change in admissions policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Schools Received Billions in Stimulus Funds. It May Not Be Doing Enough.
description: Pandemic aid was supposed to help students recover from learning loss, but results have been mixed.
content: When the pandemic shut down schools across the country, the federal government responded with billions of dollars to help districts support remote learning, serve free meals to students and safely reopen schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Jim Hines, First to Sprint 100 Meters in Under 10 Seconds, Dies at 76
description: He ran a gold-medal-winning time of 9.95 seconds at the Mexico City Olympics in 1968, setting an official world record that held for 15 years.
content: Jim Hines, who in 1968 became the first man to sprint 100 meters in under 10 seconds, and later that year won a gold medal in that distance at the Olympic Games in Mexico City with a blistering time of 9.95 seconds, a mark that stood as a world record for 15 years, died on Saturday. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitie Kelly
title: Perfumes That Conjure the American Desert
description: For today’s fragrance makers, the arid landscapes of the Southwest are fertile ground.
content: “It has been said, and truly, that everything in the desert either stings, stabs, stinks or sticks,” wrote the author and environmentalist Edward Abbey, who spent much of his life exploring the high deserts of New Mexico, Arizona and Utah. “You will find the flora here as venomous, hooked, barbed, thorny, prickly, needled, saw-toothed, hairy, stickered, mean, bitter, sharp, wiry and fierce as the animals.” Still — unsavory inhabitants notwithstanding — the arid, sandy swaths of the American Southwest have attracted generations of artists, mystics, hippies and cowboys. And now perfumers are following their lead, attempting to translate the desert’s resilient plants and otherworldly aura into fragrance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, Emily Flitter and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: S.E.C. Accuses Binance of Mishandling Funds and Lying to Regulators
description: The S.E.C. said the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange mixed billions of dollars in customer funds and secretly sent them to a separate company controlled by Binance’s founder, Changpeng Zhao.
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday accused Binance, the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, of mishandling customer funds and lying to American regulators and investors about its operations, in a sweeping case that has the potential to remake the landscape of power and wealth within crypto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: In Rare Victory for Media, Hong Kong Court Overturns Conviction of Journalist
description: A court ruled that “substantial and grave injustice” was done to Choy Yuk-ling, an investigative journalist who also goes by the name Bao Choy.
content: In a rare victory for journalism amid a crackdown on the news media in Hong Kong, the city’s top court on Monday overturned the conviction of a prominent reporter who had produced a documentary that was critical of the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Apple Debuts Its Next Big Product, a Virtual Reality Headset
description: The device, called Vision Pro and shaped like a pair of ski goggles, faces a skeptical consumer market and competition from others, like fellow tech giant Meta.
content: Apple lived up to months of expectations on Monday when it introduced new high-tech goggles that blend the real world with virtual reality. The $3,500 device, called the Vision Pro, will offer “augmented reality” and introduce “spatial computing,” Apple said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: A Political Earthquake in Texas
description: The highest levels of politics in the state are in chaos after the impeachment of a leading right-wing politician.
content: The highest levels of politics in the state are in chaos after the impeachment of a leading right-wing politician.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Mosquito Control Gear for Your Patio or Yard
source.name: The New York Times

title: The 30 Best Father’s Day Gifts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How Well Do You Know Popular Novels for Summer Reading?
description: Looking for an entertaining book to take on vacation with you? This quiz has suggestions.
content: Looking for an entertaining book to take on vacation with you? This quiz has suggestions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Deadly Flooding in Haiti Displaces Thousands
description: Heavy rainfall over the weekend caused flooding to more than 13,000 homes and displaced people across the country, according to Haiti’s disaster response agency.
content: Heavy rainfall over the weekend caused flooding to more than 13,000 homes and displaced people across the country, according to Haiti’s disaster response agency.
source.name: The New York Times
